instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD: What is WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD? This is a signal from the keyboard for the left shift key, which is significantly different from the right shift key when it comes to resetting the SMC/PRAM. .

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message:
I have a similar issue to someone with the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I believe.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. Keeps booting in Safe mode. But I figured it was due to liquid damage on the keyboard. I could hold down shift when booting and it would do a normal boot and not go into safe mode. Figured the keyboard was screwed, as it would also act like I was holding down shift while pressing any keys (letters were all CAPS and numbers were all the secondary symbols (!@#$%^&*()_+)

I replaced with a new keyboard and still has the same issue. I got frustrated last night and now am at work. I'll check between <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> and kb connector. I did clean the connector (didn't see any stickiness or corrosion, but cleaned anyway, to no avail.)

Does this sound like a trace issue?

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message: Corrosion around <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> or corrosion in the keyboard connector, pin 3 and 4. Look at diagram how the left shift works.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message: Okay thank you. I'll check it out in the next day or so and report back!! Thanks!

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 1211"]Corrosion around <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> or corrosion in the keyboard connector, pin 3 and 4. Look at diagram how the left shift works.[/QUOTE]

<CHIP>U5750</CHIP> is what was originally shorted to ground. I replaced it from a "hole" board... Do you think it could be bad still? The short has been eliminated.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message: [SIZE=10px][FONT=arial]Is <SIGNAL>WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD</SIGNAL> high? If yes then probably your keyboard connecter is bad. Or you soldered <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> wrong[/FONT][/SIZE]

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SHIFT acts like it's stuck (new keyboard, did not fix)
threads.message:
Yeah. I must have soldered it on incorrectly. Instead of trying to figure that out, I just pulled another off a board and made sure to be very deliberate with my soldering this time and no more safe mode! All seems well. Thanks again Duke!! This can be marked as fixed or solved!

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 1248"][SIZE=10px][FONT=arial]Is <SIGNAL>WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD</SIGNAL> high? If yes then probably your keyboard connecter is bad. Or you soldered <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> wrong[/FONT][/SIZE][/QUOTE]
